title: TIL the city of Nottingham, UK, named a tram after a locally born actress, Vicky McClure. On her maiden trip on the tram, she was ejected for fare evasion. Having been offered a free ride, she did not have a ticket.
TIL Jimmy Carter still lives in the same $167,000 house he built in Georgia in 1961 and shops at Dollar General

TIL that during WW2 there was a saying that "It's more likely for a snake to smoke a pipe, than for Brazil to go the front and fight", so when Brazil joined the war, their troops became known as "Cobras Fumantes", or "the Smoking Snakes".

TIL that every single copy of GoldenEye 007 for the N64 shipped with a fully functioning ZX Spectrum emulator, along with ten games, hidden on the cartridge. This function can be reenabled using an emulator, letting users play the classic games.

TIL that pineapples were so rare a sight in the 1700's they were a symbol of wealth. The few that were cultivated in hothouses were worth about five thousand pounds ($8000) each. They weren't eaten, but were rented out by the aristocracy as a table centerpiece at dinner parties.

TIL As a child, Einstein's Uncle Jakob introduced him to algebra and called it "a merry science". He compared algebra to hunting a little animal. You didn't know the name of the animal, so you called it "x". When you finally caught the animal you gave it the correct name

TIL in 2002 paramedics in Poland were arrested for killing patients and selling their information to funeral homes who would contact their relatives to make funeral arrangements. The funeral homes then added the cost of the bribes they paid the killers to the funeral bills of the victims' families.
TIL Martin Luther King criticized the FBI for failing to enforce civil rights law in the south. In retaliation he was sent a letter from the FBI calling him a fraud and asking him to kill himself.

TIL jazz violinist Joe Venuti, known for practical jokes, once called every double bass player in the New York phonebook, asking them to meet with him on a street corner; over 50 arrived with their instruments, creating a minor roadblock. Venuti later had to pay them all, as mandated by the AFM.

TIL Costco’s $6,000 Doomsday Food Kit Only Gets Your Family Through Year One of the Apocalypse. The kit is delivered as two pallets of boxes that together weigh 1,800 pounds. To keep neighbors in the dark, Costco promises everything is “packaged discreetly.” The some products expire in 30 years.

TIL: The highest point (The peak of Mount Whitney at 14,494 feet / 4,418 meters) and lowest point (The Badwater Basin area of Death Valley at -282 feet / -86 meters) in the Contiguous United States are both in California, both in the same county in California, and only 88 miles apart.

TIL during WW2, a 360 ft long prehistoric chalk horse figure on a hill in Britain, was covered over with turf and hedge trimmings so that German pilots could not use it for navigation during bombing raids.
TIL that Prince Charles has been heir to the British throne for 67 years, making him the oldest and longest-serving heir in British history.
TIL that the Illuminati is present in modern conspiracy theories largely due to some prank letters published in Playboy magazine in the 60's
TIL light bulbs in the New York City subway system screw in "backwards" (i.e. with left-handed threads) so people won't steal them to use at home.

TIL the Philippines is one of two countries, the other being Vatican City, that doesn't allow divorce. Instead, citizens have to go through an expensive & complex annulment process to circumvent the divorce ban.
TIL that Jimmy Carter's siblings and father all died of Pancreatic Cancer, with all of his siblings dying within 7 years of one another.

TIL of the Tarantula Hawk, a giant member of the wasp family whose sting is described as an "immediate, excruciating, unrelenting pain that simply shuts down one's ability to do anything, except scream. Mental discipline simply does not work in these situations." It's the state insect of New Mexico.

TIL: The only state governor to be assassinated was Kentucky’s William Goebel. He was shot soon after the election ended, and was sworn into office while on his death bed. His only official business as governor was to call off the militia looking for the person who shot him.

TIL after rigorously training dogs for space travel, Soviet scientist had a dog named Bobik run away days before their flight. A replacement named ZIB who was an untrained street dog found running around the barracks, was quickly located and made a successful flight.
TIL the oldest D20 dice was uncovered in Egypt and dates back around 30 BC

TIL: the first pilots crossing the Atlantic, crash landed on bogland in the western tip of Ireland. During their flight they came into free fall twice above the ocean. They lost the hood of the ‘cockpit’ and went trough snow and rain at 3500 m altitude, soaking and freezing them completely.

TIL about the Controversy surrounding the Four Color Theorem which states that every map can be colored using only four different colors. The remarkable theorem is the first that had to be proved using computer-assistance.
TIL Mexico City is 7200 feet above sea level which had a major affect on athletes in the 1968 Olympic games
TIL that, for a brief time, there existed a breakaway "Samurai Republic" on the island of Hokkaido that held the first-ever "democratic" elections in Japan
TIL about "The Demon Core", a mass of plutonium that was responsible for the death of two scientists on two separate occasions.
TIL Some landscaping companies use goats to get rid of invasive plant growth rather than machines and pesticides.

TIL that Marcel Marceau, the famous mime and actor, was considered a national treasure in Japan and was friends with Michael Jackson for nearly 20 years (and Jackson used a lot of his techniques in his dancing).
TIL the day after Thanksgiving is the busiest day for plumbers
TIL: In 1889 more than 50,000 people rushed to claim a piece of the available two million acres in the unassigned lands in the present-day U.S. state of Oklahoma, founding Oklahoma City.

TIL: Pedi people (a tribe in South Africa) wear Scottish kilts. Citing oral history, the use of kilts dates to 1879. They say that's when the tribe lost a battle because its warriors thought kilted Scots leading a British army were women and held their fire until realizing their mistake too late.
TIL that farmed salmon can get depression, a state which causes them to stop eating and radically changes their physical attributes
TIL In 1989, Russian psychic E. Frenkel was run over by a train while attempting to stop it with his psychic-biological power, after previously ‘successfully’ stopping a car and streetcar.

TIL To solve the problem of communicating to humans 10,000 years from now about nuclear waste sites one solution proposed was to form an atomic priesthood like the catholic church to preserve information of locations and danger of nuclear waste using rituals and myths.

TIL: That the original "Snake Oil Salesman" wasn't convicted of selling snake oil, he was convicted of selling FAKE snake oil. Oil from Chinese Water Snakes was considered a legit medicine at the time, but Clark Stanley was convicted in 1917 of selling fake snake oil.
TIL that the Yakuza is the second largest criminal organization in the world (by revenue), despite Japan being ranked 11th in worldwide population.
TIL M&M's are named after it's founder's Mars & Murrie

TIL At the top soil layer, earthworms convert fallen leaves to humus. That’s a good thing if you’re growing a garden, but, in a natural forest, it causes a fast-tracking of the release of nutrients instead. Earthworms disrupt the mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship between fungi and plants
TIL: That the gas build up from a decomposing corpse, can sometimes cause caskets to explode in mausoleums. So sometimes the caskets come with "burpers" like Tupperware.
TIL that Raymond Charles lost his face in an electrical accident in 1919, and only went out at night due to his disfigurement. Locals called him "Charlie No-Face."
TIL that Australia has the highest skin cancer rate in the world

TIL that Salieri was actually very respected during his life and was chief court composer on Habsburg Imperial Court. He and Mozart mutually respected each others and myth that Salieri poisoned Mozart was actually originated from play by Pushkin called Mozart and Salieri from 1831

TIL there is a 400-year gap between the end of events in the Old Testament of the Bible and the start of events in the New Testament. Some Protestant theologians refer to this period as "400 Silent Years" during which God did not give humankind any new information.

TIL about an indigenous kids spinning top street game in Lombok, Indonesia, called Mantek. Each region of Indonesia has its own name and rules. The kids make the tops themselves from Tamarind trees. It's played here in North Lombok by survivors of last years devastating earthquakes
TIL: Spiders have thrived in the ocean, but there are few ocean-dwelling insects and we're not sure why.
TIL The Kindlifresser, or 'Child Eater', is one of oldest statues in Bern, Switzerland and nobody is sure why it has a baby half stuffed into his mouth.
TIL a flatworm, Baicalellia daftpunka, was named after Daft Punk for having a similar shape to their helmets
TIL: Movie Theaters actually make more money from ticket sales than they do from concessions. The opposite is a common myth.
TIL In China, humans manually pollinate flowers where bees are scarce.
TIL that sleeping on the job is acceptable in Japan, as it's viewed as exhaustion from working hard.
TIL Tens of thousands of Mazda6's were recalled because spiders kept infesting the fuel systems and increasing the risk of fires.
TIL in 1900s there was a death row inmates baseball team and their executions were dependent on their performance.

TIL that there is a thirty-year-old airline that's never flown called Baltia (US Global) Airlines. For a period of 2 years, because of their mismanaged listing process, they weren't even sure if they were a public or private company
TIL that Steve Williams, Tiger Woods' Caddie until 2011, once wrestled a $7,000 camera from a fan who clicked a picture of Woods during his backswing and threw it into a pond

TIL Abraham Lincoln never said "if i knew that i had eight hours to chop a tree down, i would spend the first six sharpening my axe" - actually, the first variation on this adage first appeared in 1956, on an agricultural education paper, it was credited to an anonymous woodsman.

TIL Although there is no specialized sensory organ for time, our perception of time nevertheless depends on the rate of change in different sensory modalities. In the absence of sensory input, e.g. under anaesthesia, the sense of time is often lost or impaired.
Today I learned that the National Parks and Forests of the USA contain abandoned NASA facilities, mostly graveyards, and a natural slip and slide.
TIL that instead of dropping a "ball" on New Years Eve like New York City does, in Atlanta, Georgia they drop a peach.
TIL George Lucas' first credit on a film was as the still photographer on a movie called 'Orgy Beach Party' in 1964
TIL In the 1820s sewage was dumped directly into London's river Thames which was also used to supply drinking water.

TIL Top Gear's "tame racing driver", The Stig, would often eat his lunch in the back of an ambulance to avoid being identified. He would also remain in his racing overalls and helmet throughout the day and would put on a French-like accent when talking.

TIL in the 1993 World Chess Open, a newcomer under the name "John von Neumann" was caught cheating. When questioned by the tournament director, he could not explain basic chess concepts and was disqualified.

TIL that Hokusai, the artist behind the famous 'The Great Wave off Kanagawa', illustrated a series of shunga erotica called 'Dreams of the Fisherman's Wife' which includes vivid depictions of women having sex with octopus. Published in 1814

TIL About Robert the Devil, a medieval legend from the 13th century. Robert was the son of the devil, conceived through a satanic pact. He was extremely strong, courageous, and evil before repenting and vowing to conquer hell from his father. He is said to have saved Rome twice after turning good.
TIL Easter is named so after the pre-Christian goddess Eostre who was celebrated at the beginning of spring

[TIL] That from 1923 to 1939, the 45th Infantry Division (NG unit with members from OK, NM, CO and AZ) proudly wore a yellow swastika, an ancient Indian symbol of good luck, on a red background. Due to the rise of the Nazis, it was abandoned and a yellow Thunderbird was selected as the new insignia.
TIL Hong Kong has two ages of consent. 16 for sexual activity and 21 for a female receiving anal.
TIL of Smigus-Dyngus, known as “Wet Monday”, where traditionally on Easter Monday boys throw water over girls and spank them with pussy willow branches and girls do the same to boys.

TIL about Father Francis Gleeson, an Army chaplain during WWI. At the Battle of Ypres, among heavy casualties, he tore off the badges that marked him as a non-combatant so he could take command and hold the line.
TIL 28% of Sri Lanka's population live on less than 2$ a day, far below poverty.
TIL 10% of Americans have never left the state they were born. 40% of Americans have never left the country.
TIL Michelangelo was around 23 years old when he created the Pieta sculpture
TIL that the Monday after Easter is called Dyngus Day by Polish people, and the largest Dyngus Day celebration in the world is held in Buffalo, NY.

TIL about shot towers, formerly used to produce projectiles for shotguns. Molten lead was dropped from the top of the tower and into a bucket of water at the bottom, and the force from the fall formed spherical shots.

TIL that the sun and the moon look to be the same size because the diameter of the sun and moon and the distance to earth both share a 1:400 difference, making them look the same size, this has not been seen with any other planet-moon combination

TIL about Ferdinand Cheval, a French postman who spent 33 years of his life building his own palace using stones he collected on his daily mail trips. Although he wanted to be buried in it, the French Government refused, and he spent another 8 years building a mausoleum to complement it.
TIL that each year, churches on the Greek Island of Chios celebrate Easter by shooting thousands of rockets at each other
TIL Zuul is a genus of herbivorous ankylosaurine dinosaur named after the demon and demi-god Zuul, the Gatekeeper of Gozer, featured in the 1984 film Ghostbusters.

TIL During the naval battle of the Philippine Sea between USA and Japan, an american submarine launched a torpedo at a Japanese flagship, but the pilot Sakio Komatsu intercepted it by performing a suicide dive, detonating it

TIL the Kingdom of Eswatini (also known as Swaziland) has one of the highest rates of citizens being struck by lightening. Between 2000 - 2007 alone, there were 123 victims of lightning related death.

TIL the first movie in color was made already in 1902, the earliest color moving images ever made pre-dating 'Kinemacolor' by eight years. A British cinematographer, Edward Turner's footage of his children was found in a discovery in The National Media Museum in Bradford.
TIL: That in 2012 antifreeze manufacturers agreed to add bittering agents to antifreeze, in order to prevent children and pets from consuming it.
TIL Baseball Hall of Famer Dave Winfield was drafted by 4 teams in 3 Major League Sports coming out of college in 1973 (MLB: Padres, NBA: Hawks, ABA: Stars, NFL: Vikings)
TIL that astronauts actually get 3 percent taller while they are in space.
TIL in 1967, the mayor of Montreal negotiated a secret agreement with Charles de Gaulle for the Eiffel Tower to be dismantled and temporarily relocated to Montreal to serve as a tourist attraction

TIL commercial tea manufacturing was stolen from China in 1848 by British East India Company. They sent a Scottish botanist Robert Fortune, disguised as a merchant, to China. He brought back tea seeds, tea leaves, details of manufacturing green, and black teas and 80 Chinese tea workers!

TIL about the Solar Storm of 1859, causing damage to telegraph systems. A Solar Storm of this magnitude today would cause widespread electrical disruptions, blackouts and damage due to extended outages of the electrical grid. Such a storm entered Earth's orbit in 2012, missing Earth by only 9 days
TIL There is a Bristol stool scale to identify your poop
TIL in 2013 a piece of landing gear from one of the 9/11 flights was found wedged between two buildings in NYC.

TIL that dogs laugh and it can be used to initiate play, promote pro-social behavior, and decrease stress levels in other dogs. One study showed that playback of this recorded laughter reduced stress-related behaviors, increased tail wagging, initiated "play-face", and promoted lip licking fun
TIL that during the filming of Jackass 3D, Johnny Knoxville, Jeff Tremaine, and the rest of the crew banned beer from the set to help Steve-O maintain his sobriety.
TIL 2,153 billionaires around the world hold about US$8.7 trillion, that makes them the 3rd biggest GDP "country" in the world after china.

TIL Sham Ennessim, a holiday celebrated on the same day as Orthodox Christian Easter, is celebrated also by all Egyptians since 2700 BC till now. Next one is on the 29th of April when Egyptians go outdoors, color eggs, and eat salted fish.

TIL in the 1850's that due to mercury poisoning from taking "blue masses," Abraham Lincoln was known to have bouts of jumping up suddenly and running out of his house, as well as suddenly bursting out into laughter.
TIL The English language used to have six more letters: thorn (þ), eth (ð), wynn (ƿ), yogh (ȝ), ash (æ), and ethel (œ). They all disappeared by the 15th century.
TIL about the Shit Museum, a museum dedicated to cow shit from cows creating milk for Italian Grana Padano cheese
TIL that common everyday words such as Fart, Bra, Kiss and ahem Slut (among others) have a much more wholesome Scandinavian meaning.

TIL The 15th century Queen of France named Anne left instructions in her will for her heart to be cut out & put in a golden heart casket & that's where it's been for 500 years. For the last 130 yrs it's been on display at Thomas-Dobrée Museum until it was stolen in 2018. It has since been recovered
TIL The 1950 FIFA World Cup is the only FIFA World Cup that didn't have a final.

TIL the world’s fastest soccer player is Arjen Robben at 37 kmh (23 mph). He did this with the ball under control and after 80 min of play and scored at the end of the run. At that pace he’d run 100 m in 10.28 seconds.
TIL cats can receive a blood transfusion using canine blood once in their lives, which can be life saving.
TIL of Gyo Fujikawa, an illustrator who was an earliest mainstream illustrator who included children of many races into her picture books (which has become a common practice today).
TIL: Hypervelocity stars (designated as HVS or HV in stellar catalogues) are stars with velocities that deviate substantially from the normal velocity of stars in a galaxy.
TIL Bananas are going extinct due to a untreatable fungus breakout that's spreading around the world
TIL The Rocky Mountain locust, which once had a swarm in 1875 larger in size than the area of California, went extinct only 30 years later.

TIL Before becoming a movie star, Bruce Lee was Hong Kong’s Cha Cha champion. Lee would trade dance lessons for martial arts lessons and his first job in the United States was as a ballroom dance instructor.
TIL in the 1930's the owner of Dorney Park (Allentown, PA) built a house for his wife under the first hill of his roller coaster in order to drive her toward divorce.
TIL that some forms of oxygen are toxic to cells and may produce a significant amount of the cellular injury we associate with aging. The same thing essential to most life makes it fade away.
TIL that cold and flu viruses aren't usually transmitted via saliva.
TIL that the Future Prince of Liechtenstein will be the first heir to the deposed Catholic British Monarchy born in Britain since it was deposed
TIL China is the biggest exporter of honey in the world.

TIL that Daimler-Benz initially saw little market for G-class in US, so a small company Europa Motors did the certification and crash tests, and popularized it as an upmarket SUV. Once sales in US exploded, MB had to buy back the distribution rights in US.
TIL: Not all spiders have eight eyes! They can have two, four, six or the 'traditional' eight eyes, and one way of classifying them is by the number of eyes they have!
TIL the first recorded mention of mooning was a 1st century soldier baring his buttocks and farting in the general direction of a group of Jews celebrating Passover.

TIL that injections of malaria were used to treat patients of syphilis, manic depressive disorder, schizophrenia and HIV across the course of the 20th century, resulting in the deaths of up to 13% of those who were subject to 'malariotherapy'.
TIL Six of the warmest ten years in Ireland have occurred since 1990.

TIL there is a thought experiment in physics, which is based on the well established "Many Worlds Theory". The experiment, if right, means that you can never die because only the living you would be conscious to be aware that you are living. In essence, it means that you are immortal.
TIL Conductors are a necessary part of an orchestra. Their movements predicted the movements of their violinists, and a veteran conductor produces more aesthetically pleasing music than an amateur.
TIL Max C. Freedman wrote Rock Around the Clock when he was 59 years old
TIL that tennis star, John Patrick McEnroe's youngest brother's name is Patrick John McEnroe

TIL that penguins and other marine birds have a supraorbital gland above their eye socket that breaks down sodium in their bloodstream. Which allows them to remove salt from saltwater and make it fresh water for them to survive.
TIL Charles Bronson's, one of the toughest men in Hollywood, was so poor growing up that at one time he had to wear his sister's dress to school for lack of clothing.
TIL Border Collies are so smart that they can herd sheep with such precision as to be able to make art with them.

TIL 1981 Cadillac Eldorados were fitted with a metal plate under the driver's seat to fix a balancing problem. This saved mob associate Frank Rosenthal's life when the plate shielded him from the force of a car bomb exploding under his Eldorado.
TIL about a charity in the UK ‘adopting’ red phone boxes, removing the phone and installing lifesaving defibrillators instead.
TIL February use to be the last month of the year
TIL The record for the longest period without sleep is 11 days.
TIL that breathing 100% pure oxygen for more than 16 hours can lead to irreversible lung damage, damage to the retinas, and eventually, death.

TIL that Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge retained their UN seat until 1982, this was after the torture and genocide of an estimated 2-3 million people in their native Cambodia. Western forces refused to recognise the new Cambodian government becuase the country had been liberated by Vietnamese forces.
TIL about the War of the Ass, a 13th century conflict fought over the ownership of a donkey.
TIL about Raiders of The Lost Ark: The Adaptation a shot for shot remake of the original 1981 Indiana Jones adventure
TIL musical icon Prince was a fantastic bowler who could 'throw a strike at will' and wore knee-high furry boots while he was playing
TIL whales can drink sea water thanks to their strong kidneys
TIL - dried currents are actually dried seedless grapes 'Black Corinth'
TIL that Naspers, a South African company, owns a 31% stake in Tencent valued at over $175 billion. It bought the stake in 2001 for only $32 million.
TIL Once Spider-Man gave Mary Jane cancer through his radioactive sperm
TIL: The first time The Beatles ever got into the newspaper was because John Lennon beat up a disk jockey who asked him “How was you honeymoon with Brian Epstein” which was their manager.
TIL That Joseph Kony, of KONY 2012 notoriety and responsible for child soldiers and sex slaves, is no longer sought after by the United States or Uganda Governments.

TIL Former Canadian Prime Minister Joe Clark was punched in the face by a stranger who called him by name while walking in Montreal. Clark had declined RCMP protection, available to all former prime ministers, after he left politics

TIL in history Pope Innocent III ordered the Albigensian Crusade against Cathar Christians in Southern France. Cathar property was seized, entire towns burned, inhabitants slaughtered, and the Medieval Inquisition launched.

TIL that The King's School, a day and boarding school in Canterbury, Kent, England is the oldest continuously operating school in the world. It was founded in 597 AD by Augustine of Canterbury a century after the Fall of the Roman Empire in the West as a medieval cathedral school.

TIL that Louisiana State Penitentiary is the only prison in the US that has its own radio station. Its range isn't much wider than the penitentiary grounds. It's run by inmates, and its 24 hours of daily programming is 100% religion-based.
TIL Carlsberg, a danish beer company, used the Swastika as one of its main logos but discontinued use in the 1930s when the Swastika became associated with Nazi Germany

TIL in 2018, Chinese travellers (1.43 million) became the largest source of short-term visitor arrivals in Australia. That is a 304% increase from a decade earlier, when only 354,370 Chinese travellers visited Australia in 2008.
TIL that Carica papaya seed extract is an effective male contraceptive.

TIL that the General Sherman Tree in Sequoia National Park was originally named the Karl Marx Tree by the Kaweah Cooperative Colony, a socialist utopian community that settled on the land prior to the park's establishment.
TIL about Janet Airlines. A highly classified airline that shuttles military personnel in and out of Area 51. The name stand for 'Just Another Non-Existent Terminal'
TIL Even the sets for the apartment and bar scenes in Scrubs were built in the north hollywood hospital
TIL Of the Great Famine which plagued Europe from 1315-1317 killing an estimated 7,500,000 people.
TIL: Islam teaches that Jesus didn’t die of crucifixion, but was raised to heaven while alive. Some Christian denominations believe this as well.
TIL That in Souris Prince Edward Island it is illegal to have a snowman taller than 30 inches (2.5 feet)
TIL 'Hey Diddle Diddle' (a nursery rhyme) is over 500 years old.
TIL The Vehicle Assembly Building at NASA's Kennedy Space Center is so big that it has its own weather system, with clouds forming below the ceiling on very humid days.
TIL that concentric exercise (when muscles contract) isn't as effective at building muscles as eccentric exercise ("going against the negative") when the latter is done correctly.
TIL that John Hale, a California resident, has ridden the Disneyland attraction Radiator Springs Racers over 10,000 times over the course of 5 years
TIL of boxwood miniatures, prayer aids, detailed sculptures 15cm in diameter, from the 15th and 16th centuries.
TIL the word 'bus' is actually short for 'omnibus' meaning "To contain many things" and didn't originate until the early 19th century
TIL that Pineapples grow on bushes, and not on trees.
TIL Ducks should be fed frozen peas instead of bread.
TIL The original script for Beetlejuice was much darker with Beetlejuice taking the form of a rabid squirrel and mutilating the Deetz' 9-year old daughter in the final scene.
TIL that the inventor of the magnetic stripe card used a flat iron to make the first prototype
TIL that crime rates in Mexico drop significantly whenever footballer Javier "Chicharito" Hernandez is playing.
TIL that an M1 Abrams Tank runs on a 1500hp Gas Turbine Engine, not a diesel as commonly assumed, that runs at 3000 rpm after a 10:1 reduction gear set.
TIL People used to play chess across the globe by mailing their moves to each other

TIL Charles Stratton AKA General Tom Thumb was a diminutive relation who worked for PT Barnum, and became an internationally acclaimed stage performer. He is credited with changing the perception of “freak shows”, which were previously seen as base work, and they soon after became highly popular.
TIL That today in history, Commander John Paul Jones lead a raid on the port town of Whitehaven, England during the American Revolution.

TIL that male sharks have two penises called “claspers”, which develop due to a gene called the Sonic hedgehog gene. This gene causes a variety of body parts to develop, and if the gene is expressed in female sharks as long as it’s expressed in male sharks, they also develop two claspers.
TIL that Cymru the Welsh name for Wales means friends or companions, but the English name Wales derives from the germanic word walh which means stranger or foreigner.

TIL Charles Darwin reportedly took Harriet the Tortoise from the Galapagos Ilands to England. It was then transported to Australia where it was more recently visited by Steve Irwin. The tortoise lived 175 years.

TIL that Led Zeppelin had become so frustrated with reporters and interviewers that officials had put down strict rules for anyone who went backstage. One of those rules stated "Do not make any sort of eye contact with John Bonham. This is for your own safety."
TIL the Romans had a toilet pantheon, including the great sewer goddess Venus Cloacina - whom you prayed to when the toilet clogged - and Crepitus, whom you prayed to when you were constipated

TIL learned about Pink Floyd's lost album 'Household Object's'. There are only two known tracks (linked below). The album was created after Dark Side of the Moon. When asked about it, the band can be quoted in saying the album was too weird even for them.

TIL the Ryugyong Hotel in North Korea is the world's shortest building with at least 100 floors. It is 330m tall (1082 feet) and has 105 floors. Meanwhile, Shanghai World Financial Center is 162m/530ft taller for only 101 floors.
TIL that NASA has robot astronauts called Robonauts

TIL in 1978 British explorer Tim Severin proved it was possible for a 6th century Irish boat clad in leather to make the journey across the Atlantic from Ireland to North America. This was done to test if St. Brendan the Navigators described journey across the Atlantic was possible at the time.

TIL of Harry Daghlian, a 24 year-old physicist with the Manhattan Project. He accidentally dropped a brick into the centre of a plutonium core and exposed himself to a lethal dose of radiation, dying 25 days after the accident.
TIL of Denise Harvey. A Florida woman who had sex with a 16 year old on her sons baseball team. She got 30 years but fled to Canada which granted her asylum
TIL that giraffes sleep using their own butts as pillows
TIL There is a Japanese art for called Dorodango, which is where earth and water are moulded and polished to make very shiny balls

TIL that the US reached peak coal mining employment in 1923, when there were 883,000 coal miners employed in the US. Today, there are only 50,000 coal miners in the US. Nevertheless, the US produces about 50% more coal than it did 100 years ago.
TIL that 31 prisoners in a prison in Uganda escaped because the guards were busy trying to catch a rabbit. The rabbit evaded capture.
TIL that China has launched and successfully recovered satellites with wooden heat shields

TIL legendary musician Prince passed away leaving no will detailing how to distribute his multi-million dollar estate. Within 3 weeks of his death, more than 700 people claimed to be his half-sibling or descendant.
TIL hydropower comprises nearly 100% of electricity production in Paraguay, and 90% of energy generated is exported mainly to Brazil and Argentina.
TIL that the main producer behind The Legend of Zelda CD-i games, Dale DeSharone, also owned Boston Animation, the company behind the educational kids' game M&Ms The Lost Formulas.
TIL Movie theatre popcorn is sold at a 1275% markup
TIL Simon Bolivar decreed that permitted any atrocities committed against people born in Spain that weren't actively working with the revolutionaries

TIL Ernst & Young (EY), setup in 1989 through a merger, has its roots under 2 individuals - Arthur Young & Alwin C. Ernst. They never met and both passed away within days of each other in 1948.Today, EY has over 231,000 employees globally.
TIL that the Antarctic Point of Inaccessibility has a Lenin Bust that has survived 50 years without any maintenance
TIL, in 2018 the Sagrada Familia Church agreed to pay Barcelona $41M as fine for lacking a building permit for 136 Years
TIL The first federally funded US-Mexico border fence went up in 1911. But it wasn't built to keep people out. Instead, it was meant to stop tick-infested cattle from wandering into the U.S.
TIL about Eddie Gaedel, the smallest person to ever play in the Major Leagues. His jersey number was 1/8.
TIL Hitler in his teenage years was attracted to a girl named Stefanie Isak, a girl who's believed to have Jewish origins.

TIL Inner verbalization of the mind is accompanied by tiny muscular movements in the larynx. Neuroscientists have also found that an area within the left inferior frontal gyrus, known as Broca’s area, is active when we speak out loud and also during inner speech.

TIL of the Free Little Library organization. Comprised of over 80,000 locations in 91 countries, this service allows any individual or organization to set up a public book sharing station where community members can freely give or take books.
TIL at the end of the Diamond Sūtra - the oldest surviving dated printed book - is a note that the creator was told to copy out the book by his parents
TIL that insects don't have lungs. They just kinda absorb oxygen and it is related to their size, i.e. why bugs got so big when the Earth had more oxygen.

TIL Peppa Pig was endorsed by the People's Liberation Army and Chinese weapons manufacturer Norinco, who have performed military formations composing of soldiers and tanks in the shape of the cartoon's signature character.

TIL the BBC wanted to broadcast Band of Brothers so much that not only did they spend £7 million on securing broadcast rights, but PM Blair personally oversaw the deal and supervised negotiations with Steven Spielberg
TIL Queens song 39, while at first seeming about soldiers going to war, is actually about astronauts on an Interstellar Voyage returning to a far future Earth due to relativistic time-dilation
